briefdescription.para: Default constructor.

detaileddescription.para: Constructs a bitmap object with no data; an assignment or another member function such as Create() or LoadFile() must be called subsequently.

briefdescription.para: Copy constructor, uses reference counting.

detaileddescription.para: To make a real copy, you can use:

memberdef.argsstring: (const char bits[], int width, int height, int depth=1)
memberdef.name: wxBitmap

briefdescription.para: Creates a bitmap from the given array bits.

detaileddescription.para: You should only use this function for monochrome bitmaps (depth 1) in portable programs: in this case the bits parameter should contain an XBM image.

For other bit depths, the behaviour is platform dependent: under Windows, the data is passed without any changes to the underlying CreateBitmap() API. Under other platforms, only monochrome bitmaps may be created using this constructor and wxImage should be used for creating colour bitmaps from static data.

bits
Specifies an array of pixel values.
width
Specifies the width of the bitmap.
height
Specifies the height of the bitmap.
depth
Specifies the depth of the bitmap. If this is omitted, then a value of 1 (monochrome bitmap) is used.
wxPerl Note: In wxPerl use Wx::Bitmap->newFromBits(bits, width, height, depth).

briefdescription.para: Creates a new bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: A depth of wxBITMAP_SCREEN_DEPTH indicates the depth of the current screen or visual.
Some platforms only support 1 for monochrome and wxBITMAP_SCREEN_DEPTH for the current colour setting.
A depth of 32 including an alpha channel is supported under MSW, Mac and GTK+.

parameterdescription.para: The width of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The height of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The number of bits used to represent each bitmap pixel.

briefdescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.
Create a bitmap compatible with the given DC, inheriting its magnification factor.

parameterdescription.para: The width of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The height of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
DC from which the scaling factor is inherited

simplesect.para: 3.1.7 (previously available only in wxMSW and wxOSX ports).

briefdescription.para: Creates a bitmap from XPM data.

detaileddescription.para: wxPerl Note: In wxPerl use Wx::Bitmap->newFromXPM(data).

briefdescription.para: Loads a bitmap from a file or resource.

parameterdescription.para: This can refer to a resource name or a filename under MS Windows and X. Its meaning is determined by the type parameter.

May be one of the wxBitmapType values and indicates which type of bitmap should be loaded. See the note in the class detailed description. Note that the wxBITMAP_DEFAULT_TYPE constant has different value under different wxWidgets ports. See the bitmap.h header for the value it takes for a specific port.

briefdescription.para: Creates this bitmap object from the given image.

detaileddescription.para: This has to be done to actually display an image as you cannot draw an image directly on a window.
The resulting bitmap will use the provided colour depth (or that of the current system if depth is wxBITMAP_SCREEN_DEPTH) which entails that a colour reduction may take place.
On Windows, if there is a palette present (set with SetPalette), it will be used when creating the wxBitmap (most useful in 8-bit display mode). On other platforms, the palette is currently ignored.

parameterdescription.para: Platform-independent wxImage object.
Specifies the depth of the bitmap. If this is omitted, the display depth of the screen is used.

briefdescription.para: Creates a bitmap compatible with the given DC from the given image.

detaileddescription.para: This constructor initializes the bitmap with the data of the given image, which must be valid, but inherits the scaling factor from the given device context instead of simply using the default factor of 1.

parameterdescription.para: Platform-independent wxImage object.
DC from which the scaling factor is inherited

simplesect.para: 3.1.7 (previously this constructor overload was only available in wxMSW port)

briefdescription.para: Creates bitmap corresponding to the given cursor.

detaileddescription.para: This can be useful to display a cursor as it cannot be drawn directly on a window.

parameterdescription.para: A valid wxCursor.

briefdescription.para: Destructor.

detaileddescription.para: See Object Destruction for more info.
If the application omits to delete the bitmap explicitly, the bitmap will be destroyed automatically by wxWidgets when the application exits.

simplesect.para: Do not delete a bitmap that is selected into a memory device context.

briefdescription.para: Returns disabled (dimmed) version of the bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: This method is not available when wxUSE_IMAGE == 0.

briefdescription.para: Creates an image from a platform-dependent bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: This preserves mask information so that bitmaps and images can be converted back and forth without loss in that respect.

briefdescription.para: Creates the bitmap from an icon.
Creates a fresh bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: If the final argument is omitted, the display depth of the screen is used.

parameterdescription.para: The width of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The height of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The number of bits used to represent each bitmap pixel.

simplesect.para: true if the creation was successful.

briefdescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.
Create a bitmap compatible with the given DC, inheriting its magnification factor.

parameterdescription.para: The width of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The height of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
DC from which the scaling factor is inherited

simplesect.para: true if the creation was successful.

briefdescription.para: Create a bitmap specifying its size in DPI-independent pixels and the scale factor to use.

detaileddescription.para: The physical size of the bitmap is obtained by multiplying the given size by scale and rounding it to the closest integer.
After using this function the following postconditions are true:

listitem.para: GetSize() returns size multiplied by scale

parameterdescription.para: The size of the bitmap in DPI-independent pixels. Both width and height must be strictly positive.
Scale factor used by the bitmap, see SetScaleFactor().
The number of bits used to represent each bitmap pixel.

simplesect.para: true if the creation was successful.

memberdef.argsstring: (int width, int height, double scale, int depth=wxBITMAP_SCREEN_DEPTH)
memberdef.name: CreateWithDIPSize

briefdescription.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

memberdef.argsstring: (int width, int height, int depth, double logicalScale)
memberdef.name: CreateScaled

briefdescription.para: Create a bitmap with a scale factor.

detaileddescription.para: This is an older synonym for CreateWithDIPSize(), use the new function in the new code.

parameterdescription.para: The width of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The height of the bitmap in pixels, must be strictly positive.
The number of bits used to represent each bitmap pixel.
Scale factor used by the bitmap, see SetScaleFactor().

simplesect.para: true if the creation was successful.

briefdescription.para: Gets the colour depth of the bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: A value of 1 indicates a monochrome bitmap.

briefdescription.para: Returns the size of bitmap in DPI-independent units.

detaileddescription.para: This assumes that the bitmap was created using the value of scale factor corresponding to the current DPI (see CreateWithDIPSize() and SetScaleFactor()) and returns its physical size divided by this scale factor.
Unlike GetLogicalSize(), this function returns the same value under all platforms and so its result should not be used as window or device context coordinates.

briefdescription.para: Returns the height of the bitmap in physical pixels.

simplesect.para: GetWidth(), GetSize(), GetLogicalHeight()

briefdescription.para: Returns the height of the bitmap in logical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: See GetLogicalSize() for more information.

simplesect.para: GetLogicalWidth(), GetWidth()

briefdescription.para: Returns the size of the bitmap in logical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: For the platforms using DPI-independent pixels, i.e. those where wxHAS_DPI_INDEPENDENT_PIXELS is defined, such as wxOSX or wxGTK 3, this function returns the physical size of the bitmap, as returned by GetSize(), divided by its scale factor, as returned by GetScaleFactor(), while for the other platforms, it simply returns the same thing as GetSize().

This ensures that the result of this function is always expressed in the pixel coordinates appropriate for the current platform, i.e. its return value is always in logical pixels, used for window and wxDC coordinates, whether these pixels are the same as physical pixels, which are returned by GetSize(), or not.

simplesect.para: GetLogicalWidth(), GetLogicalHeight(), GetSize()

briefdescription.para: Returns the width of the bitmap in logical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: See GetLogicalSize() for more information.

simplesect.para: GetLogicalHeight(), GetWidth()

briefdescription.para: Gets the associated mask (if any) which may have been loaded from a file or set for the bitmap.

simplesect.para: SetMask(), wxMask

briefdescription.para: Gets the associated palette (if any) which may have been loaded from a file or set for the bitmap.
Returns a sub bitmap of the current one as long as the rect belongs entirely to the bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: This function preserves bit depth and mask information.

briefdescription.para: Returns the scale factor of this bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: Scale factor is 1 by default, but can be greater to indicate that the size of bitmap in logical, DPI-independent pixels is smaller than its actual size in physical pixels. Bitmaps with scale factor greater than 1 must be used in high DPI to appear sharp on the screen.
Note that the scale factor is only used in the ports where logical pixels are not the same as physical ones, such as wxOSX or wxGTK3, and this function always returns 1 under the other platforms.

simplesect.para: SetScaleFactor(), GetLogicalWidth(), GetLogicalHeight(), GetLogicalSize()

briefdescription.para: Returns the height of the bitmap in logical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: This is an older synonym for GetLogicalHeight(), use the new function in the new code.

briefdescription.para: Returns the size of the bitmap in logical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: This is an older synonym for GetLogicalSize(), use the new function in the new code.

briefdescription.para: Returns the width of the bitmap in logical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: This is an older synonym for GetLogicalWidth(), use the new function in the new code.

briefdescription.para: Returns the size of the bitmap in physical pixels.

detaileddescription.para: The return value of this function doesn't depend on the scale factor, it is always the physical size of the bitmap, i.e. corresponding to the actual number of pixels in it.

simplesect.para: GetHeight(), GetWidth(), GetLogicalSize()

briefdescription.para: Returns the width of the bitmap in physical pixels.

simplesect.para: GetHeight(), GetSize(), GetLogicalWidth()

briefdescription.para: Returns true if the bitmap has an alpha channel.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the fact that a bitmap has an alpha channel doesn't necessarily mean that it has any transparency, as all of its pixels could be using wxALPHA_OPAQUE value. To actually examine the alpha values, the bitmap can be converted to wxImage.

briefdescription.para: Returns true if bitmap data is present.
Loads a bitmap from a file or resource.

parameterdescription.para: Either a filename or a Windows resource name. The meaning of name is determined by the type parameter.

One of the wxBitmapType values; see the note in the class detailed description. Note that the wxBITMAP_DEFAULT_TYPE constant has different value under different wxWidgets ports. See the bitmap.h header for the value it takes for a specific port.

simplesect.para: true if the operation succeeded, false otherwise.
A palette may be associated with the bitmap if one exists (especially for colour Windows bitmaps), and if the code supports it. You can check if one has been created by using the GetPalette() member.

briefdescription.para: Remove alpha channel from the bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as calling UseAlpha() with false argument.

memberdef.argsstring: (const wxString &name, wxBitmapType type, const wxPalette *palette=NULL) const
memberdef.name: SaveFile

briefdescription.para: Saves a bitmap in the named file.

parameterdescription.para: A filename. The meaning of name is determined by the type parameter.
One of the wxBitmapType values; see the note in the class detailed description.
An optional palette used for saving the bitmap.

simplesect.para: true if the operation succeeded, false otherwise.
Depending on how wxWidgets has been configured, not all formats may be available.

xrefdescription.para: This function is deprecated since version 3.1.2, dimensions and depth can only be set at construction time.

detaileddescription.para: Sets the depth member (does not affect the bitmap data).

parameterdescription.para: Bitmap depth.

xrefdescription.para: This function is deprecated since version 3.1.2, dimensions and depth can only be set at construction time.

detaileddescription.para: Sets the height member (does not affect the bitmap data).

parameterdescription.para: Bitmap height in pixels.

briefdescription.para: Sets the bitmap scale factor.

detaileddescription.para: This doesn't change the bitmap actual size or its contents, but changes its scale factor, so that it appears in a smaller size when it is drawn on screen: e.g. setting scale to 2 means that the bitmap will be twice smaller (in each direction) when drawn on screen in the ports in which logical and physical pixels differ (i.e. wxOSX and wxGTK3, but not wxMSW).
When creating a new bitmap, CreateWithDIPSize() can be used to specify the correct scale factor from the beginning.

briefdescription.para: Sets the mask for this bitmap.

simplesect.para: The bitmap object owns the mask once this has been called.
A mask can be set also for bitmap with an alpha channel but doing so under wxMSW is not recommended because performance of drawing such bitmap is not very good.
GetMask(), wxMask

briefdescription.para: Sets the associated palette.

detaileddescription.para: (Not implemented under GTK+).

parameterdescription.para: The palette to set.

xrefdescription.para: This function is deprecated since version 3.1.2, dimensions and depth can only be set at construction time.

detaileddescription.para: Sets the width member (does not affect the bitmap data).

parameterdescription.para: Bitmap width in pixels.

briefdescription.para: Enable or disable use of alpha channel in this bitmap.

detaileddescription.para: This function is only useful for 32bpp bitmaps and changes their format to use, or not use, the fourth byte of the pixel data for the alpha channel.
It currently is only implemented in wxMSW and wxOSX and simply always returns false under the other platforms.

simplesect.para: true if the operation succeeded, false otherwise, e.g. when trying to enable alpha channel support for a non-32bpp bitmap or if this operation is simply not supported by the current platform.
HasAlpha(), ResetAlpha()

briefdescription.para: Adds a handler to the end of the static list of format handlers.

detaileddescription.para:
handler
A new bitmap format handler object. There is usually only one instance of a given handler class in an application session.
Note that unlike wxImage::AddHandler, there's no documented list of the wxBitmapHandlers available in wxWidgets. This is because they are platform-specific and most important, they are all automatically loaded at startup.
If you want to be sure that wxBitmap can load a certain type of image, you'd better use wxImage::AddHandler.

briefdescription.para: Deletes all bitmap handlers.

detaileddescription.para: This function is called by wxWidgets on exit.

briefdescription.para: Finds the handler with the given name.

simplesect.para: A pointer to the handler if found, NULL otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Finds the handler associated with the given extension and type.

parameterdescription.para: The file extension, such as "bmp" (without the dot).
The bitmap type managed by the handler, see wxBitmapType.

simplesect.para: A pointer to the handler if found, NULL otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Finds the handler associated with the given bitmap type.

parameterdescription.para: The bitmap type managed by the handler, see wxBitmapType.

simplesect.para: A pointer to the handler if found, NULL otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Returns the static list of bitmap format handlers.
Adds the standard bitmap format handlers, which, depending on wxWidgets configuration, can be handlers for Windows bitmap, Windows bitmap resource, and XPM.

detaileddescription.para: This function is called by wxWidgets on startup.

briefdescription.para: Adds a handler at the start of the static list of format handlers.

parameterdescription.para: A new bitmap format handler object. There is usually only one instance of a given handler class in an application session.

briefdescription.para: Loads a bitmap from the memory containing image data in PNG format.

detaileddescription.para: However under macOS this function uses native image loading and so doesn't require wxWidgets PNG support.

briefdescription.para: Finds the handler with the given name, and removes it.

detaileddescription.para: The handler is not deleted.

parameterdescription.para: The handler name.

simplesect.para: true if the handler was found and removed, false otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Rescale the given bitmap to the requested size.

detaileddescription.para: This function is just a convenient wrapper for wxImage::Rescale() used to resize the given bmp to the requested size. If you need more control over resizing, e.g. to specify the quality option different from wxIMAGE_QUALITY_NEAREST used by this function, please use the wxImage function directly instead.
Both the bitmap itself and size must be valid.

briefdescription.para: This class encapsulates the concept of a platform-dependent bitmap, either monochrome or colour or colour with alpha channel support.

detaileddescription.para: If you need direct access the bitmap data instead going through drawing to it using wxMemoryDC you need to use the wxPixelData class (either wxNativePixelData for RGB bitmaps or wxAlphaPixelData for bitmaps with an additionally alpha channel).

In addition, wxBitmap can load and save all formats that wxImage can; see wxImage for more info. Of course, you must have loaded the wxImage handlers (see wxInitAllImageHandlers() and wxImage::AddHandler). Note that all available wxBitmapHandlers for a given wxWidgets port are automatically loaded at startup so you won't need to use wxBitmap::AddHandler.

More on the difference between wxImage and wxBitmap: wxImage is just a buffer of RGB bytes with an optional buffer for the alpha bytes. It is all generic, platform independent and image file format independent code. It includes generic code for scaling, resizing, clipping, and other manipulations of the image data. OTOH, wxBitmap is intended to be a wrapper of whatever is the native image format that is quickest/easiest to draw to a DC or to be the target of the drawing operations performed on a wxMemoryDC. By splitting the responsibilities between wxImage/wxBitmap like this then it's easier to use generic code shared by all platforms and image types for generic operations and platform specific code where performance or compatibility is needed.
Library:wxCore
Category:Graphics Device Interface (GDI)
Predefined objects/pointers: wxNullBitmap

simplesect.para: Bitmaps and Icons, Supported Bitmap File Formats, wxDC::Blit, wxIcon, wxCursor, wxMemoryDC, wxImage, wxPixelData
